title: RStudio Integration
text:
RStudio Integration
You can use git and GitHub within RStudio. Via the interface you can stage files, create commits or push and pull from and to remote repositories.
For more info, check out the official RStudio User Guide on Version Controll


Configure R Studio Integration

title: Repository examples on GitHub
text:
https://github.com/HannaMeyer/CAST
In R, you can directly install the package from GitHub using the following commands:

devtools::install_github(repo = "https://github.com/HannaMeyer/CAST")

remotes::install_github(repo = "https://github.com/HannaMeyer/CAST")

The install.packages function by default downloads and installs packages from CRAN which in itself is a repository for R packages and their version management.

install.packages("CAST")

Package Page created with pkgdown: https://hannameyer.github.io/CAST



https://github.com/LOEK-RS/global_applicability



The materials for my Introduction to R Course are stored in a repository on GitHub:









https://github.com/mlspatial/analysis_of_ecological_data
Through GitHub pages the repository is automatically rendered and published as a website: https://mlspatial.github.io/analysis_of_ecological_data
You can also find the files of this git course and homepage on GitHub:

title: Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
section: The problems we are trying to solve
text:
The problems we are trying to solve



messy files

title: Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
text:
Publishing

Methods Article
Presentation of new analytical techniques, new software, etc., or critical evaluation of methods in macroecology. Typically, these papers do not exceed ten printed pages.
Open Research
Global Ecology and Biogeography supports open research, therefore expects that the data supporting the results in the paper will be archived in an appropriate public repository, […] Whenever possible the scripts and other artefacts used to generate the analyses presented in the paper should also be publicly archived in a repository

title: Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
text:
Publishing
Code Availability
The code to reproduce the results presented in this study can be accessed at: https://github.com/LOEK-RS/global_applicability. The methods for the forward variable selection, area of applicability and dissimilarity index calibration are implemented in the R package ‘CAST’: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/CAST/index.html. (Ludwig et al. 2023)
Providing Software
All newly produced R functions and modelling steps are fully documented in https://github.com/HannaMeyer/CAST. (Meyer et al. 2018)

title: Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
text:
What is git?


Version Control System
Developed by Linus Torvalds to work on the Linux Kernel with multiple people
Mainly for Code, but useful for many other things

title: Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
Introduction to git and GitHub for LOEK
text:
References


Ludwig, Marvin, Alvaro Moreno-Martinez, Norbert Hölzel, Edzer Pebesma, and Hanna Meyer. 2023. “Assessing and Improving the Transferability of Current Global Spatial Prediction Models.” Global Ecology and Biogeography 32 (3): 356–68. https://doi.org/10.1111/geb.13635.


Meyer, Hanna, Christoph Reudenbach, Tomislav Hengl, Marwan Katurji, and Thomas Nauss. 2018. “Improving Performance of Spatio-Temporal Machine Learning Models Using Forward Feature Selection and Target-Oriented Validation.” Environmental Modelling & Software 101 (March): 1–9. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2017.12.001.





Introduction to git

https://miro.medium.com/max/700/1*9qX9F9MGsWKfcmgTOR9BPw.png



Command Line Tool
GUI Versions available, e.g. GitHub Desktop
Application with a learning curve
Core unit: A repository

There is an excellent StackOverflow Thread on the difference between the workspace and the repository.


```{shell}
git init   # to start

git status # to get infos

git add    # to add files to the tracking system

git commit # to define changed files as the new standard
```

https://miro.medium.com/max/700/1*9qX9F9MGsWKfcmgTOR9BPw.png



Command Line Tool
GUI Versions available, e.g. GitHub Desktop
Application with a learning curve
Core unit: A repository

There is an excellent StackOverflow Thread on the difference between the workspace and the repository.


```{shell}
git init   # to start

git status # to get infos

git add    # to add files to the tracking system

git commit # to define changed files as the new standard
```

GitHub










Cloud Storage for git repositories
platform for code sharing, documentation, (data)…
collaboration and (scientific) communication

Besides the plain storage in a cloud environment, GitHub offers a variatey of documentation and collaboration features:

Wiki
Issue - Tracker
Automation
GitHub Pages


GitHub related commands on the command line



https://miro.medium.com/max/700/1*9qX9F9MGsWKfcmgTOR9BPw.png


```{sh}
git remote    # to get infos about remote

git push      # to send commits to remote

git pull      # to download commits from remote

git clone     # to download a repository
```

Setup










Get git

https://git-scm.com/download/
preinstalled on most GNU/Linux distributions

```{sh}
# minimum prerequisit configuration
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
```


GitHub

create a GitHub Account
ssh?

Get Started
About Git
SSH Authentification

Collaboration with git and GitHub
There are excellent workshop resources by the US National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis on how to use git, GitHub and RStudio for collaborative research: https://pages.github.nceas.ucsb.edu/lter/github-workshop/index.html
They also go through the basic git concept, but also tackle more collaboration specific topics like merge conflicts and forks.





Using GitHub and RStudio as a collaborative tool needs some considerations and practice to prevent merge conflicts.
